results.title: Balls of Steel for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM in CD jewel case with insert and manual
results.brief_description:
Balls of Steel is a top-down pinball computer game that features five fully-animated pinball tables, each with its own theme, missions, and special bonuses. One of the tables is themed on Duke Nukem, a franchise that Balls of Steel’s publisher, Apogee Software, developed. This tie-in continues to Duke Nukem series itself, where the pinball game appears in several releases.

Balls of Steel plays on a top-down scrolling screen, with an animated dot matrix display at the bottom mimicking the displays of actual pinball tables. As with its real-life counterpart, it shows the player score and animated graphics. Each table can also be viewed in its entirety. High scores are awarded with a “powerball” bonus mode, and could be posted on the “WorldScores” website for a global ranking, although this feature has since been discontinued.

results.title: Bad Street Brawler for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, manual and blurb card in cardboard box
results.brief_description: In Bad Street Brawler, the player plays the character Duke Davis, a former punk rocker and the “world’s coolest” martial artist. Duke has to work his way through each level beating up the crooks that get in his way. Before the start of the next stage, quotes are introduced to entertain the player, such as “Never trouble trouble until trouble troubles you”. The player’s moves are limited to kicks and punches but new moves and attacks become available as the game progresses, along with new enemy types such as gorillas flinging bananas, menacing stakeboarders and circus strongmen. Bad Street Brawler is one of two games designed specifically for Mattel’s Power Glove.

results.title: Aussie Rules Footy for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge sleeve and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Aussie Rules Footy is a sports game based on Australian Rules Football. The game is played from a third-person perspective, where the player has the ability to perform the basic actions of the footy player currently in posession of the ball. A player can pick one of eighteen Australian football teams to compete against the computer, or against another player on the same system. The game includes a Kick to Kick Training Session, a Single Game mode and a Season mode where one, four or six players can play multiple games that culminate in the Grand Final.

A player wins by having the most points at the end of the game. Points are added by either kicking a goal (six points) or a behind (one point). To move the football, a player with the ball can either kick or handball the ball, and a player without the ball can either mark the ball or tackle an opposition player with the ball. The game was only released in Australia.

To move the football, a player with the ball can either kick or handball the ball, and a player without the ball can either mark the ball or tackle an opposition player with the ball. results.title: If at first you don’t succeed
results.brief_description: Since 2015, Celeste Barber’s resisted the swarm of unattainable images on social media with her #celestechallengeaccepted project, an experiment to see how normal people look recreating the perfectly staged poses of the rich and Insta-famous

constellations_primary.name: If at first you don't succeed
constellations_primary.description: Though originally intended as a laugh, Celeste Baber’s social media posts have become examples of body positivity to her eight million followers and challenge the absurd expectations put on women in society.

results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Smartphones aren’t a mirror, but the images and videos influencers and celebrities post on social media can seem like standards we should reflect. Australian comedian Celeste Barber isn’t aspiring to these unrealistic ideals. Since 2015, Barber’s resisted the swarm of air-brushed and unattainable images with her #celestechallengeaccepted project, an experiment to see how normal people look recreating the perfectly staged poses of the rich and Insta-famous. Though originally intended as a laugh, Barber’s posts have become examples of body positivity to her eight million followers and challenge the absurd expectations put on women in society.
description_for_label:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Smartphones aren’t a mirror, but the images and videos influencers and celebrities post on social media can seem like standards we should reflect. Australian comedian Celeste Barber isn’t aspiring to these unrealistic ideals. Since 2015, Barber’s resisted the swarm of air-brushed and unattainable images with her #celestechallengeaccepted project, an experiment to see how normal people look recreating the perfectly staged poses of the rich and Insta-famous. Though originally intended as a laugh, Barber’s posts have become examples of body positivity to her eight million followers and challenge the absurd expectations put on women in society.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Videogames and Us
results.brief_description: Since videogames were first invented in laboratories, our relationship to play has evolved. From arcades and the first home consoles to today’s blockbuster releases, mobile games and experimental indies, how we interpret and experience vieogames has changed alongside us.

constellations_primary.name: Arcades and AI
constellations_primary.description: Using the godfather of computing, Alan Turing, as a starting point, this Constellation traces the evolution of AI representation on-screen and the way female androids, robots and holograms have been hyper sexualised.

results.description: Play is an essential part of who we are as individuals and as a collective. Since videogames were first invented by scientists in laboratories, our relationship to play has come a long way. From arcades and the first home consoles to today’s blockbuster releases, mobile games and experimental indies, videogames have evolved dramatically and so have we. How we interpret and experience videogames, and the communities and cultures spawned from them, reveals much about how society has shifted in the past five decades.
description_for_label: Play is an essential part of who we are as individuals and as a collective. Since videogames were first invented by scientists in laboratories, our relationship to play has come a long way. From arcades and the first home consoles to today’s blockbuster releases, mobile games and experimental indies, videogames have evolved dramatically and so have we. How we interpret and experience videogames, and the communities and cultures spawned from them, reveals much about how society has shifted in the past five decades.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Games Lab → GL-05. Videogames Infographic → GL-05-C01

results.title: Entities
results.creator_credit: OOM Creative, MORE Studio, Greg More (OOM Creative), Pete Brundle (MORE Studio) and James Sandri (MORE Studio)
results.brief_description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

constellations_primary.name: Future visions
constellations_primary.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

results.creator_credit_for_label: OOM Creative, MORE Studio, Greg More (OOM Creative), Pete Brundle (MORE Studio) and James Sandri (MORE Studio)
results.description:
We leave a trace whenever we interact with a digital system: a thread of data that lingers like a ghost within a machine.

Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections. Each time an object is collected, the visualisation updates in real-time to create a dynamic living map of our visitors’ journey: the more people in the space, the more active it becomes. Created by code and contemporary web technologies, Entities encourages visitors to discover new objects and artworks by seeing what others are collecting in the gallery over time.
description_for_label:
We leave a trace whenever we interact with a digital system: a thread of data that lingers like a ghost within a machine.

Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections. Each time an object is collected, the visualisation updates in real-time to create a dynamic living map of our visitors’ journey: the more people in the space, the more active it becomes. Created by code and contemporary web technologies, Entities encourages visitors to discover new objects and artworks by seeing what others are collecting in the gallery over time.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Constellation

results.title: Videogames supercut
results.brief_description: Today’s videogames focus as much on emotion as they do action. Through evolving technical expertise and the power of narrative, character and story are now as vital to a memorable gaming experience as ammo clips and power-ups.

constellations_primary.name: Action, emotion and videogames
constellations_primary.description: More and more, videogames are beginning to favour emotion as much as action, just like their film and TV cousins.

results.description: Today’s videogames focus as much on emotion as they do action. Through evolving technical expertise and the power of narrative, character and story are now as vital to a memorable gaming experience as ammo clips and power-ups. This video interweaves scenes from AAA, indie games and everything in-between to explore the emotional impact of games, as well as the white-knuckle tension of battle, how time can be manipulated for dramatic effect and how artistic expressions like movement and dance are bringing a human element to gaming.
description_for_label: Today’s videogames focus as much on emotion as they do action. Through evolving technical expertise and the power of narrative, character and story are now as vital to a memorable gaming experience as ammo clips and power-ups. This video interweaves scenes from AAA, indie games and everything in-between to explore the emotional impact of games, as well as the white-knuckle tension of battle, how time can be manipulated for dramatic effect and how artistic expressions like movement and dance are bringing a human element to gaming.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → MA-04. Music Video

results.title: Dream a Little Crazy – Architecture in Helsinki
results.brief_description: Renowned for their colourful and crazy videos, Architecture in Helsinki’s clip for Dream A Little Crazy (2013) is no exception. A collaboration between body architect Lucy McRae and designer Rachel Wingfield, the music video presents a “biological bakery” as it creates an edible anatomy.

constellations_primary.name: Dream A Little Crazy: The next stage of human evolution
constellations_primary.description: Collaborators Lucy McRae and Rachel Wingfield created a ‘biological bakery’ for Architecture In Helsinki’s "Dream A Little Crazy". Manufacturing a series of mass-produced band members the clip explores speculative science and the future of the human body’s evolution.

results.title_for_label: Dream a Little Crazy – Architecture in Helsinki
results.description: Renowned for their colourful and crazy videos, Architecture in Helsinki’s clip for ‘Dream A Little Crazy’ was no exception. A collaboration between body architect Lucy McRae and designer Rachel Wingfield, the music video presents a “biological bakery” as it creates an edible anatomy. The Melbourne alt-pop darlings pointed to properties such as The Rocky Horror Picture Show (1975), Weird Science (1985) and Frankenstein as influences for the concept.
description_for_label: Renowned for their colourful and crazy videos, Architecture in Helsinki’s clip for ‘Dream A Little Crazy’ was no exception. A collaboration between body architect Lucy McRae and designer Rachel Wingfield, the music video presents a “biological bakery” as it creates an edible anatomy. The Melbourne alt-pop darlings pointed to properties such as The Rocky Horror Picture Show (1975), Weird Science (1985) and Frankenstein as influences for the concept.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → MA-04. Music Video

results.title: Delusional World
results.brief_description:
Lu Yang’s dizzying virtual world is a neon dreamscape lurking in our networks. Exploring digital voyeurism and online cultures, “Delusional World” summons audiences to our new online gallery to encounter a frenetic collision of Chinese mythology, sci-fi futures and live performance.

This free mind-bending, hyper-pop performance features a contemporary dancer fitted with motion capture technology, who projects fantastical digital avatars of the artist that materialise as deranged deities, Manga-inspired mutants and cyborgs. Live-streamed from Chronus Art Centre in Shanghai, this experimental performance presents a darkly humorous virtual world where the audience and artist interact through a live chat.

Source: ACMI webpage for Lu Yang Delusional world, last accessed 27/10/2020
results.description:
Lu Yang’s dizzying virtual world is a neon dreamscape lurking in our networks. Exploring digital voyeurism and online cultures, Delusional World summons audiences to our new online gallery to encounter a frenetic collision of Chinese mythology, sci-fi futures and live performance.

This free mind-bending, hyper-pop performance features a contemporary dancer fitted with motion capture technology, who projects fantastical digital avatars of the artist that materialise as deranged deities, Manga-inspired mutants and cyborgs. Live-streamed from Chronus Art Centre in Shanghai, this experimental performance presents a darkly humorous virtual world where the audience and artist interact through a live chat.

Delusional World was commissioned by ACMI, Arts Centre Melbourne, Asia TOPA and Exhibitionist, in collaboration with curator Mathew Spisbah, Chronus Art Centre and Meta Objects. It was presented as part of Asia TOPA 2020.

Lu Yang’s dizzying virtual world is a neon dreamscape lurking in our networks. Exploring digital voyeurism and online cultures, “Delusional World” summons audiences to our new online gallery to encounter a frenetic collision of Chinese mythology, sci-fi futures and live performance.

Live-streamed from Chronus Art Centre in Shanghai, this experimental performance presents a darkly humorous virtual world where the audience and artist interact through a live chat.
